Topic.Title: Bloomberg: Nokia's speed advantage opens ways to gain on iPhone

Message.Msg: Nokia Lumia 920 vs HTC Windows Phone 8X: Obvious low inventory changes game December 2, 2012, 10:00 P.M., Sunday, New York local time — HTC and its retail and operator partners start shipping the new HTC Windows Phone 8X, meanwhile, Nokia is controlling the Nokia Lumia 920 inventory for unknown reason. It is quite obvious that the HTC Windows Phone 8X is not suffering from low inventory. We’ve been told that HTC started shipping its new Windows Phone 8X, and third-party retailers and retailers are now shipping orders with 1-week shipping time. At one popular online retail store, the HTC Windows Phone 8X is available in two colors, the black and the blue model. With a cheaper price tag of $600 off-contract and with an unlocked micro-SIM card slot. Other colors such as the red and green (lime) are not yet available. For comparison, the Nokia Lumia 920 is still backordered or on-preorder with December 5 to 10 shipping debut. The Nokia Lumia 920 is also expensive at $750 off-contract price tag with unlocked micro-SIM card slot. A retailer said the Nokia Lumia 920 is more popular than the HTC Windows Phone 8X, but low inventory is affecting sales. We’ve been told that the Yellow Nokia Lumia 920 is the most popular variant to date. In United States, the largest carrier, Verizon Wireless, is selling the Windows Phone 8X with unlocked SIM card slot for $199.99 with 2-year contract or $549.99 at full price. Worth noting is the carrier logo on the HTC Windows Phone 8X which may not as cool for some customers. Verizon’s LTE coverage and popularity might help the HTC Windows Phone. Speaking of popularity, Nokia’s Lumia 920 is an exclusive device of AT&T’s 4G LTE network. The device, according to Amazon Wireless chart, is the most popular smartphone of the carrier (excluding the iPhone) after outselling the quarter and a half old Samsung Galaxy S3 AT&T LTE. For starters, the Windows Phone 8X of HTC is powered by Qualcomm MSM8960 Snapdragon dual-core Krait processor with Adreno 225 GPU, 1GB RAM and Windows Phone 8 operating system out of the box. The device features a 4.3-inch S-LCD2 display with 720 x 1280 pixels boasting 342 pixels per inch. The HTC 8X with Windows Phone 8 also includes an 8-megapixel primary camera and a front-facing 2.1-megapixel secondary camera with wide-angle shooting capability. For comparison, the Nokia Lumia 920 is sporting the same Qualcomm dual-core Krait processor, 1GB RAM and Windows Phone 8 operating system on board. The device features a 4.5-inch IPS TFT display with 768 x 1280 pixels and 332 pixels per inch. The best feature of the Nokia Lumia 920 is its 8.7-megapixel PureView camera and its stunning build quality. SOURCE: PopHerald ________ Note: Qualcomm provides the LTE modem for BOTH the Nokia Lumina 920 and the HTC Windows Phone 8X phones. Proving ibexx88 is full of baloney. Again. lol

Message.Title: Apple sells 27 million iPhones and 14 million iPads last quarter.
Message.Msg: Apple sells 27 million iPhones and 14 million iPads last quarter. Apple sold 27 million iPhones and 14 million iPads in the last quarter of 2012, swelling its revenue by 27 percent. Apple's net profit for the quarter, ended Sept. 29, was US$8.2 billion, or $8.67 per share, up sharply from $6.6 billion, or $7.05 per share, in the same quarter a year earlier, the company announced Thursday. Apple sold 58 percent more iPhones than in the same quarter last year, while iPad shipments were up 26 percent, it said. Mac sales weren't so strong, growing 1 percent to 4.9 million units, while iPod sales continued to decline, falling to 5.3 million, as more people relied on their smartphones to listen to music. "We're very proud to end a fantastic fiscal year with record September quarter results," CEO Tim Cook said in a statement. SOURCE: Computerworld ________ Note: While Apple sold 58 percent more iPhones (27 million units), and 26 percent more iPads (14 million units) than in the same quarter last year, Mac sales weren't so strong, growing just 1 percent to 4.9 million units.

Topic.Title: Apple sells 27 million iPhones and 14 million iPads last quarter.

Message.Msg: So ibbey? With shipments of the Genuine iPhone UP +58%, and the Genuine iPad UP +26%, the Mac is like, dying, right? In a relative sense. Up just 1% from a year ago.

Topic.Title: Apple sells 27 million iPhones and 14 million iPads last quarter.

With shipments of the Genuine iPhone UP +58%, and the Genuine iPad UP +26%, yet the Mac was only up a mini-scule 1% versus last year, well, the Mac is a flat, going-nowhere business. Probably explains why Qualcomm went for the LTE parts for the iPhone and iPad. 'Cause ya always want to be where the high-growth volume is, right boys?

Topic.Title: Wow, amd up over 7%, NVDA Down almost 2 %

Message.Msg: AMD is on the verge of bankruptcy, in part, due to the poor margins on low cost chips and their only high margin product is about to be taken away by NVIDIA as Apple is moving to NVIDIA's Kepler based GPU's. AMD and Intel are too firmly associated with the Windows OS and low end PC market which, if you've been paying attention, is being eroded by that market segment choosing mobile devices. AMD doesn't have a footprint here and never will. As for Intel, despite having the capital to buy up patents or companies in this space they've clearly shown they don't understand the segment with the flop of the Atom not to mention being way late to the game. Something else to be said is that NVIDIA makes a lot of it's money on high end servers and gaming pc's which, consequently, is the only die hard PC market left and as Apple gets a stronger hold in the enterprise MS/Intel/AMD will further decline - let's face x86 is an antiquated technology and relatively expensive and the only way Intel can stay the same size without charging bucket loads more for its processors is for it to sell in large volumes. Volumes, which I want point out, simply just aren't there in the high end server market. NVIDIA is coming out with T3/T4 - (with Kepler DNA) SOC with SDR LTE modem which makes it's mobile package very attractive as it is only one of two SDR approved vendors for SDR on AT&T. Finally, there is Kepler in the cloud (GeForce Grid) which has been adopted (again beating Intel to the game) Gaikai and gives NVIDIA another foothold in an emerging market not to mention giving them an edge in the mobile client to server graphics integration for mobile gaming and cloud based applications. NVIDIA is well diversified, well managed and is a leader or emerging competitor in several key markets. Neither of the companies you've mentioned can say that as they are all but one trick ponies - Qualcom is the only company you've mentioned that is positioned well, good company, but again they are pretty much isolated to the mobile market and honestly I think the Grey with the T4 will give it's crapdragon a run for it's money.

Topic.Title: Why Has Nvidia Gone Completely Silent?

Message.Msg: The probable replacement of Qualcomm for nvidia in the Microsoft Surface RT 2 has likely caused a major earthquake at the corner of Walsh Avenue and the San Tomas Expressway in Santa Clara. A Major Earthquake, boys. Causing the nvidia Board to be asking pointed questions about Jen's tegra folly. Oh so many many questions. Such as, "Does it make any sense to be IN the mobile processor business any longer? Hummm? Texas Instruments threw in the towel, and they had like Nine (9) times the mobile market share of nvidia. Freescale just call it quits too, and AMD hired all their mobile chip engineers. And with the Tegra/Consuming Profits Business on track to Lose $311,000,000.00 -- nearly a Third of a Billion Dollars -- of shareholder's cash this year, aren't we just throwing good money after bad at this point?" Hummm? Do we REALLY think icera can ever catch-up with Qualcomm in connectivity? Hummm? With so many many questions from the Board, Jen is kinda busy right now. And has no time for carnival barking about this and that. 'Cause this and that might not be around much longer.

Topic.Title: Why Has Nvidia Gone Completely Silent?

Message.Msg: China mobile runs on a TD-SCDMA network and they are currently converting to a TDD-LTE network for about 200,000 sites. FYI, the TDD-LTE is “NOT” supported by ICERA. Unless Tegra 3 is working with a Qualcomm’s modem MDM9615 I doubt it very much that China Mobile will have a smartphone that uses Tegra 3.
